title-group.article-title: Hypertrophic olivary degeneration after surgical resection of brain tumors

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Hypertrophic olivary degeneration (HOD) can be seen as high signal intensity with enlargement of the inferior olivary nucleus (ION) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance (MR) images 4–6 months after injury of the Guillain-Mollaret triangle. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no systematic evaluation with regard to the relationship between neurosurgical intervention affecting this pathway and the appearance of HOD.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: To evaluate MR findings of HOD after surgical resection of brain tumors with the temporal evolution in focus.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: MR images of seven patients that showed signal changes in the ION after surgical resection of brain tumors in the posterior fossa were retrospectively reviewed. T1-weighted imaging with and without gadolinium (Gd) contrast enhancement and T2-weighted imaging were performed in all patients before and after surgery.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Before surgery, no patient had a signal change in the ION. T2-high signal intensity of the ION initially appeared 5 days to 2.5 months after surgery. Five patients showed enlargement of the ION with T2-high signal intensity 11 days to 3.5 months after surgery: three patients showed the enlargement of the ION subsequent to the T2-signal change on serial follow-up MR images. On Gd-enhanced T1-weighted images, there was no enhancement at the ION in any patient. Each signal change of the ION was consistent with HOD, according to the relationship between the resection site of the tumor and the Guillain-Mollaret triangle on follow-up MRI.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: HOD can be caused after neurosurgical intervention of brain tumors involving the Guillain-Mollaret triangle. It is important for radiologists to distinguish HOD from tumor recurrence.

Hypertrophic olivary degeneration (HOD) is a unique transsynaptic degeneration caused by lesions in the Guillain-Mollaret triangle. The Guillain-Mollaret triangle is defined by three anatomical structures: the dentate nucleus (DN) in the cerebellum, the contralateral red nucleus at the level of the mid-brain, and the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus (ION) in the medulla oblongata. The DN afferents travel via the superior cerebellar peduncle (SCP) to the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, fibers descend in the central tegmental tract (CTT) to enter the ION. The ION sends its afferents via climbing fibers in the inferior cerebellar peduncle to Purkinje cells of the contralateral cerebellar cortex. The Purkinje cells send their afferents to the ipsilateral DN, thus completing the triangle (1–3). Disruption of this triangle results in three possible patterns of presentation. When the primary lesion is limited to the CTT, HOD is ipsilateral, as only ipsilateral fibers are affected. When the primary lesion is in the DN or in the SCP, HOD is contralateral, and when the lesion involves both the CTT and the SCP, HOD is bilateral.

On magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), T2-prolongation in the inferior olivary nucleus (ION) occurs about 3 weeks after insult, such as cerebrovascular disease affecting the pathway. Enlargement of the ION is not seen immediately after the insult but is typically delayed, usually appearing within 4–6 months. An atrophic ION is demonstrated on MR images after a few years (4–7).

Although disconnection of the Guillain-Mollaret triangle is most frequently caused by hemorrhage and infarction, several cases of HOD following neurosurgical intervention have been reported (4–14). In terms of brain tumors, there are a few reported cases in the literature describing HOD on MR imaging occurring after surgical resection (7–14).

To the best of our knowledge, no systematic evaluation with regard to the relationship between neurosurgical interventions in the Guillain-Mollaret triangle and temporal evolution of HOD on follow-up MR images has been reported based on case series. The purpose of this study was to evaluate MR findings of HOD after surgical resection of brain tumors involving the Guillain-Mollaret triangle.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Serial MR imaging of seven patients (six women and one man; mean age, 38.1 ± 28.3 years; range, 2–79 years) with signal changes of the ION after surgical resection of brain tumors were retrospectively reviewed. Before surgery, no patient showed signal changes of the ION. The location and histology of the primary tumors were as follows: fibrillary astrocytoma in the left cerebellum (patient 1), metastasis from breast cancer in the right cerebellum (patient 2), metastasis from lung cancer in the left cerebellum (patient 3), ependymoma in the fourth ventricle (patient 4), medulloblastoma in the fourth ventricle (patients 5 and 6), and brainstem glioma (patient 7). Patients 1 and 2 underwent surgery twice, initial tumor resection and secondary total resection 16 months after initial resection in patient 1, and initial total resection and secondary total resection of recurrent tumor 8.3 months after initial total resection in patient 2.

High intensity and enlargement of the ION on T2-weighted images were determined by referring to images of healthy patients as well as by comparing images of the contralateral ION. MR examinations were performed before and after surgical resection of the primary tumor using 1.5-T scanners (Signa CVNV, GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA or Magnetom Vision, Siemens, Erlangen, Germany or EXCELART vantage XGV, Toshiba, Tochigi, Japan) in three patients and 3-T scanner (Signa EXCITE HD, GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA) in four patients, which included axial T1-weighted images with and without gadolinium (Gd) contrast enhancement (1.5-T scanner: TR/TE, 600–665 ms/11–14 ms; flip angle, 70°; slice thickness, 5–6 mm; field of view [FOV], 23 cm; matrix size, 288 × 416/3-T scanner: TR/TE, 9.092 ms/1.976 ms; flip angle, 13°; slice thickness, 5 mm; FOV, 21 cm; matrix size, 512 × 512) and axial T2-weighted image (1.5-T scanner: TR/TE, 3600–4000 ms/86.92–96 ms; flip angle, 180°; slice thickness 5–6 mm; FOV, 23 cm; matrix size, 288 × 416/3-T scanner: TR/TE/excitations, 5000 ms/93.44 ms; flip angle, 90°; slice thickness, 5 mm; FOV, 21 cm; matrix size, 512 × 512). Images of all patients were retrospectively reviewed by two neuroradiologists (YS and TK or YS and TO) who interpreted the images together and reached a consensus in terms of findings. The retrospective study protocol was approved by the institutional review board.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Clinical data of seven patients with signal changes in the ION following surgical resection of brain tumors are shown in Table 1. All signal changes of the ION on follow-up T2-weighted images were compatible with the secondary transsynaptic degeneration compared to the relationship between the resection site of the tumor and the Guillain-Mollaret triangle. There was no contrast enhancement at the ION on any patient on Gd-enhanced T1-weighted images. T2-high signal intensity of the ION initially appeared 5 days to 2.5 months (median, 21.5 days) after surgery. Among seven patients, five patients showed enlargement of the ION with T2-high signal intensity 11 days to 3.5 months (median, 1.7 months) after surgery: three patients showed enlargement of the ION after the T2-signal change on serial follow-up MR images (patients 1, 5, and 7) and two patients showed both enlargement and T2-high signal intensity of the ION on initial follow-up MR images (patients 4 and 6). The other two of the seven patients showed no enlargement of the ION on serial follow-up MR images (patients 2 and 3). T2-high signal intensity of the ION persisted at the end of the observation in each patient (from 11 days to 15.7 months; median, 7.4 months). Enlargement of the ION persisted from 11 days to 13.6 months (median, 4.6 months), while one patient (patient 5) showed atrophy of the ION 5.7 months after surgery.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: There are a few reported cases in the literature describing HOD on MRI occurring after surgical resection of brain tumors (8–14). Two recent reported cases detailed HOD after surgery for cerebellar glioma and posterior fossa epidermoid, respectively (12, 13). Bontozoglou et al. presented a case of HOD after surgical resection of cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma involving the DN (14). As far as we know, this report is the first published description of HOD after surgical resection of various brain tumors that frequently generate in the posterior fossa, including metastasis, ependymoma, medulloblastoma, and gliomas. We recently reported a case of HOD after gamma-knife radiosurgery (GKRS) for pontine metastasis involving the left CTT (15). In that case, the ION showed normal appearance on MR images before GKRS. However, MR images 2.8 months after GKRS showed T2-hyperintensity and hypertrophy of the left ION without Gd enhancement, although the pontine metastasis was smaller. Interestingly, HOD rarely occurs simply by the brain tumors in the Guillain-Mollaret triangle without surgical intervention, as shown in our case series (15–17). Destructive histological damage to the Guillain-Mollaret triangle, enough to cause disconnection of this pathway may be needed to cause HOD.

Although the MRI findings of the ION were consistent with the HOD in this study, the interval from surgical resection to enlargement of the ION on MR images (11 days to 3.5 months) was shorter than that from cerebrovascular disease (4 to 6 months) as previously reported (4–7). Taking pathological characteristics of HOD described by Goto et al. into consideration (18), the initial MR change of T2-prolongation at the ION may relate to the initial phase of neuronal hypertrophy, in which gliosis and increased water content are associated with demyelination and vacuolization, and the enlargement of the ION is likely the result of neuronal and astrocytic hypertrophic precursors to cell death. We speculate that histopathological changes of the ION in surgical intervention occur more rapidly than those in cerebrovascular disease, due to the difference of the degree and extent of the histological damage involving this neural connection.

One of the clues to the diagnosis of HOD is the association of the resection site. HOD will be the most likely diagnosis if the signal change of the ION is associated with another lesion in the contralateral DN, the contralateral SCP, the ipsilateral red nucleus, or the pontine tegmentum including the CTT on MRI. In addition, another significant clue to the diagnosis will be lack of contrast enhancement within the enlarged ION (3, 19). Because many kinds of malignant brain tumors demonstrate good contrast enhancement (20), Gd-enhanced T1-weighted imaging may be useful for distinguishing HOD from tumor recurrence.

Some limitations should be noted in the present study. First, we did not evaluate serial MR images after surgical resection of brain tumors in the posterior fossa prospectively, but evaluated those in patients with signal changes of the ION following surgical resection retrospectively. Second, we could not standardize the MR scanner to use in each case. However, it seems that no gross error would be generated by the difference in MR scanners because the HOD on MRI could be clearly observed in our study.

In conclusion, HOD may develop after neurosurgical intervention of a brain tumor involving the Guillain-Mollaret triangle with early appearance of an enlarged ION. HOD must be distinguished from tumor recurrence when T2-prolongation with or without ION enlargement affecting the Guillain-Mollaret triangle is detected on postoperative MRI.
